title: (x) Vintage looking serif face - Poor Richard {Nick Curtis}
content:

author: rickruss

comments.content: Not it, but [Metropolis](http://web.archive.org/web/20120125075550/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/spiecegraphics/metropolis-sg/) has a similar feel.
Kinda feels a bit like Cochin too.
And there is a touch of University...

I believe it's [Poor Richard](http://web.archive.org/web/20120125075550/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/redrooster/poor-richard-rr/poor-richard-rr/) (although the sample is one year off)...

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20120125075550im_/http:/typophile.com/files/poor-richard_5457.png)

I agree...it's like a hodgepodge of several fonts. The crossbar on the "e" doesn't connect on the left (like Banjoman) and the "g" has a number 8 appearance (sort of like Al Koch Antiqua and Locarno - only connected). Long ascenders (like Bernadette and University Roman) and a large bowl on the "a"(exaggerated, resembling Kabel).

Attached is a larger sample. Thanks for your help.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20120125075550im_/http:/typophile.com/files/Type-2_3961.gif)
WE HAVE A WINNER! Poor Richard it is. OMG, thank you so much!

Kinda also looks like Bodoni Classic Hand.

EDIT: Ooops, I was a little late on the draw.
It's is Poor Richard. I made the first film font of that in 1965. I had it in 72 point metal and then was transformed into a photo-lettering face.

To get the alternate 'g' used in the image, try the [Phil's Fonts version](http://web.archive.org/web/20120125075550/http:/www.philsfonts.com/detail.html?sku=PF00002401P2) - it's a tad less expensive to boot.
